discourse_list.title: Breaking News: Ex- Coinbase Manager, Two Others Indicted In Alleged $1.1 Million Crypto Insider Trading Scheme

content.content: According to the SEC this is historic. Enforcement is heating up as predicted. Because of bad actions this space will be regulated. As I like to say it is best to be prepared and I think this is just the start. The SEC calls  $AMP, $RLY, $DDX, $XYO, $RGT, $LCX, $POWR, $DFX, and $KROM “crypto asset securities" so let’s see where this goes. Below see links for more information.    justice.gov – 21 Jul 22    Three Charged In First Ever Cryptocurrency Insider Trading Tipping Scheme      Here is the indictment : https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/press-release/file/1521186/download

I will never forget the day that it was reported that Coinbase would go public, with that any small mistake they make or an irrigation gap where the regulators can get in will be very bad for everything that surrounds Coinbase, and I dare not say that this is the tip of the iceberg, we can assume that regulators are more accurate with crypto than with classic companies that cheat, this is the bad side of the real world, I keep insisting on reducing exposure to USDC.

Moi:  I keep insisting on reducing exposure to USDC.   Interesting point. I see that sentiment fairly often on the forum. Generally I think there is more to come. Once there is discovery, assuming it gets to that stage, there should be a fair amount coming out. And I suspect other exchanges and platforms will be next. One of the intriguing things to me is how the SEC is almost using these defendants as a way to get to some other issues, like essentially saying certain tokens are basically securities or something close to it.

Exactly, when you look at the report you say “Oh wow, a relative, friend, gossip about his company” that could happen even in the most powerful companies, but since it is crypto, they are more hostile, you know what they say, innovation gives fear, and more when that innovation harms you. And I know they committed a crime, but I could not exaggerate saying that if this is done by a conventional company there is not as much bragging as if crypto did it.
Moi:  And I know they committed a crime   Well they are only allegations as this point.

Not surprisingly, there is much more going on here. Now it appears Coinbase is a target arising out of another probe. This is very significant for the entire crypto space. The results of this could impact the overall market at high levels.    Reuters – 26 Jul 22    Crypto exchange Coinbase faces SEC probe over securities - Bloomberg News The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating whether Coinbase Global Inc improperly let Americans trade digital assets that should have been registered as securities, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.

It was odd that Coinbase switched from “only supporting a handful of bluechip cryptos” to “rapidly adding in a bunch of random garbage”. I hope that is the focus of the investigation rather than the SEC using this as an excuse to label legitimate projects a securities.

Yup, I agree. Coinbase should bear the brunt of this. But they have the resources and they aren’t backing down so this should be interesting. Also, procedurally, it gets messy because there is a related criminal case being presently prosecuted so there really is a lot at play. Some might argue the SEC is making noise so they still are as relevant as the CFTC which might be given more power (and money). This all just underscores the need for legislation to use as guidance as opposed to nothing but enforcement actions.

MFeinberg:  This all just underscores the need for legislation to use as guidance as opposed to nothing but enforcement actions.   +1 to this: enforcement actions and court cases are a terrible way to enact policies and clarify the law, particularly in a space as complex as crypto.
